title: 109_hr3559
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005". It includes beneficiary protections. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 includes beneficiary protections and amendments to quality standards and exemptions in the competitive acquisition program under the Social Security Act. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 amends exemptions for smaller metropolitan statistical areas with a population of less than 500,000 and applies the Federal Advisory Committee Act to the Program Advisory and Oversight Committee. The effective date of these amendments is retroactive to the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 includes small supplier protections. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 includes provisions for qualified supplier participation and restoration of due process in administrative and judicial reviews. The Act allows small businesses to continue participating as suppliers at selected award prices if they submit bids below the fee schedule amount and comply with program requirements. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 amends the process for administrative and judicial reviews, requiring significant savings of at least 10 percent for program implementation. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 amends the process for administrative and judicial reviews, requiring significant savings of at least 10 percent for program implementation. The Secretary must conduct a comparability analysis before implementing certain rates in non-competitive acquisition areas. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 mandates a comparability analysis before applying bid rates in non-competitive acquisition areas to ensure cost-effectiveness and beneficiary access to quality items and services under section 1847. The Medicare Durable Medical Equipment Access Act of 2005 requires a comparability analysis before implementing bid rates in non-competitive acquisition areas for items described in section 1847(a)(2)(B) or (2)(C) starting from January 1, 2009. The amendments made by this section will be effective as if part of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003.
